findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) lacks a structured, scalable system to map Veterans Affairs Schedule for Rating Disabilities (VASRD) codes to standardized medical codes. This gap makes it difficult for adjudicators to efficiently evaluate claims, leading to processing delays and inconsistent evaluations. Amida’s MCP team currently performs this mapping manually, which is time-consuming and not scalable.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count)

findings.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
findings.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

Additional filtering reduced ECEU results from 2,517 to 1,703 codes, improving precision while retaining alignment with 141 of the 147 source codes identified in the SME’s manual process. This refinement increases approach accuracy without sacrificing coverage.

findings.description: Heading 4 style mismatch: font 'Lato Italic' → 'Lato Italicized'; color RGB color_type:None → RGB 0-8-14; size 12.0 → 11; spacing-before unknown → 0; spacing-after unknown → 2. Expected per Amida Style Guide (Headings).
findings.found_text: This table compares ECEU results across multiple medical conditions. Each row lists a condition and its associated VASRD code, detailing the clinical code mapping. The "Source Codes" column displays the initial validated codes, while the "ECEU Results“ column captures the unfiltered mapping output. The "Filtered ECEU Results" column highlights the significant reduction in false positives after LLM processing, ranging from 43% (Sarcoidosis) to 77% (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). The "Common Codes" column confirms retention of over 90% of source codes for most conditions, while “Missing Codes” tracks minimal losses. This comparative analysis demonstrates how our approach substantially improves precision in VASRD-to-medical code and preserves comprehensive coverage across diverse medical conditions.

findings.found_text: These images show Step 1 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool. Users enter three key inputs: a 4-digit VASRD code (comma-separated for multiples), the associated disability (e.g., “Sarcoidosis,” as shown in the right-hand image), and the desired coding standard (as shown within the dropdown menu in the right-hand image). After providing the necessary input, the users select the "Step 2: Generate Keywords" button to proceed.

findings.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
findings.found_text: These images show Step 2 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, where the system generates and displays extracted and expanded keywords according to inputs from Step 1. After clicking "Generate Keywords" in the previous step, the system processes the given input and presents a table of relevant medical terms associated with the condition. LLMs automatically extract these terms from eCFR descriptions and expand them based on the specified disability. The system filters these keywords to retain only those relevant to the disability, removing any duplicates or unnecessary terms to create a focused set of medical mapping terminology.

findings.found_text: This image shows the final step (Step 3) of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, which displays the complete VASRD to ICD-10 mapping results. After the UMLS API processes the keywords, the system presents a comprehensive table of filtered medical codes matched to the selected VASRD code and disability. The panel on the left-hand side shows a summary view of the results, while the image on the right-hand side displays the full expanded view, including all mapped codes. To save these mapping results, users click the "Download Final Result CSV" button.

findings.found_text: Figure 24 – The diagram illustrates a workflow for calculating cosine similarity between eCFR descriptions and ICD-10 descriptions. Step 1 involves obtaining the eCFR description, followed by preprocessing the textual data to clean and standardize it. In Step 2, both eCFR and ICD-10 descriptions are fed into an embedding model, which converts the text into numerical vector representations. The ICD-10 Description is extracted from the output retrieved through the UMLS API. In Step 4, vectors are stored for further use. Finally, Step 5 utilizes cosine similarity to measure the degree of similarity between the eCFR description and ICD-10 description.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 25– This code snippet demonstrates a preprocessing function called preprocess_ecfr. The function tokenizes the input text into words, converts them to lowercase for uniformity, and removes common stopwords to focus on meaningful terms. It lemmatizes the tokens, reducing them to their base or root form, and removes punctuation and special characters to eliminate unnecessary noise. Additionally, duplicate words are removed while preserving the order of occurrence. Finally, the cleaned tokens are joined back into a single string. This cleaning process is crucial because the eCFR descriptions contain a lot of noise and repeated words, making them unsuitable for embedding and similarity measurement.

Vector embedding is performed using four models, the best model is finalized by analyzing the results to determine the most effective one for the project.

findings.found_text: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved 33 matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had 28 matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only 1 code. PubMedBERT and BioBERT yielded fewer matches in the top 200 results because their embeddings focus on biomedical text, which may not align well with the regulatory and clinical language in the ECFR description, resulting in weaker semantic connections

findings.found_text: Figure 30 -  Cosine similarity analysis was implemented to quantify the textual relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions. The computed similarity scores exhibited a range from 0.6876 to 0.8870 in the API output results, while Hannah's codes demonstrated scores from 0.7099 to 0.8870. Although cosine similarity excels at measuring textual alignment between vector representations, the substantial overlap in score distributions suggests its limitations in distinctly separating the approved codes from the broader API output set. This overlap presents a significant challenge in reliably identifying and ranking the 147 validated codes within the top 500 results.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 31 – Euclidean distance is used to measure the similarity between two points. In this analysis, vector embeddings were generated for the Sarcoidosis ECFR description and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions using the text-embedding-3-large. Without applying normalization or dimensionality reduction, the L2 norm is calculated. ICD-10 Codes were sorted based on their L2 norm scores, with lower scores indicating higher similarity. The top 200 codes with the lowest L2 norm scores were compared to a curated list of 147 Sarcoidosis-related ICD-10 codes. Among the top 200 codes, 20 matched the curated list, and in the top 500, 29 codes matched. While the match is limited, refining the ECFR description by incorporating all known symptoms of Sarcoidosis using a LLM has the potential to improve the relevance and accuracy of the results.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 32 -  In our analysis, Euclidean distance serves as a key metric to evaluate the semantic relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions across two distinct datasets: API output results and Hannah's codes. The API output encompasses 2,564 codes, while Hannah's dataset contains 147 thoroughly validated codes. Our Euclidean distance calculations revealed a distribution ranging from 0.4754 to 0.7904 in the API dataset and 0.4754 to 0.7617 in Hannah's dataset. Notably, the overlapping distance ranges indicate that Euclidean distance, may not provide optimal differentiation for identifying the 147 validated codes within the broader API Output Results.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 33 - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.

findings.found_text: Figure 33 - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.
findings.suggestion: Figure thirty-three - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately seventy-five,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 34 – The image shows the Voronoi polygon for Sarcoidosis. Voronoi is performed for 6 ECFR health conditions. For detailed analysis, we focused on one seed point, Sarcoidosis. From the Voronoi results, we identified 5,487 ICD-10 codes (data points) associated with Sarcoidosis (seed point). To evaluate these results, we compared them with Hannah's team's result, which contains 147 ICD-10 codes related to Sarcoidosis. Out of Voronoi's identified codes, 47 matched the existing list. While the match is limited, this result reflects some inherent challenges. Each data point is assigned to only one seed point region, which might not fully capture cases where data points could relate to multiple health conditions. Additionally, the dimensionality reduction step (PCA), though essential for visualization, may have contributed to minor distortions in the clustering.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Table 3 - The table illustrates how data points are distributed among four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, based on embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. Voronoi partitioning was applied using cosine similarity, which assigns each data point to the seed point with the highest similarity. This method allows for the grouping of data points based on their similarity to the seed points, providing a structured way to categorize ECFR descriptions. By examining these groupings, we gain valuable insights into the relationships and relevance of ICD-10 codes to each seed point, shedding light on how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

findings.found_text: Table 4 - The table shows how data points are distributed among the four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, which are based on the embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. To analyze the data, Voronoi partitioning was applied using Euclidean distance. This method assigns each data point to the nearest seed point by calculating the Euclidean distance between the data point and the seed points. This approach helps identify patterns and relationships between ECFR descriptions and their closest seed points, offering a structured way to group similar data. By analyzing these groupings, we gain insights into the relevance of each seed point to the ICD-10 codes, uncovering how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 35 - The figure illustrates the architecture of a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. The process begins by embedding ICD-10 code descriptions into a vector embeddings using text-embedding-3-large embedding model. These embeddings are stored in a vector database to enable efficient semantic search. When a user submits a health condition as a query, it is converted into a vector embedding and passed to a retriever, which searches the vector database to find the most relevant ICD-10 descriptions. The retrieved information is then fed into a large language model (LLM), which combines this contextual input with its pretrained knowledge to generate a comprehensive and query-specific response. This integrated process of retrieval and generation ensures precise, relevant, and highly contextualized outputs for medical code queries.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 36 – This work builds upon the concepts discussed in Slide 26, extending the implementation to refine the RAG pipeline for ICD-10 code retrieval and generation. The RAG pipeline combines vector embeddings and LLM to retrieve ICD-10 codes based on input queries. Vector embeddings are generated for ICD-10 code descriptions and stored in a FAISS index utilizing IndexFlatL2, which relies on L2 norm (Euclidean distance) for similarity searches. During the retrieval process, an embedding is generated for the input query and compared with the stored embeddings to retrieve the top k results. The retrieval process is configured with k=500, the top 500 most relevant ICD-10 codes are retained based on similarity ranking. Analysis shows that only 29 of the ICD-10 codes matched within the top 500 results, leaving 118 ICD-10 codes unretrieved. Since the generation process in RAG relies on the retrieved data, any missing codes in the retrieval stage are inherently excluded from the generation phase. This dependency emphasizes that the quality and completeness of the retrieved data directly impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the generated results. Without retrieving all relevant codes, the generated output may fail to capture the full scope of the input query, making the current RAG approach insufficient.

findings.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
findings.found_text: Figure 38 - This diagram demonstrates our conceptual framework for graph-based ICD-10 filtering. Here we visualize the (synthetic) connectivity patterns between ICD-10 (dark blue dots) and VASRD codes (light blue dots). The diagram showcases two distinct patterns of code relationships: Looking at the top section, we see examples of indiscriminate ICD-10 codes (marked in the red boxes) that are overconnected to multiple VASRD nodes. These create a complex web of relationships, indicating low selectivity and a high probability of false positives. Such codes are less useful for precise medical classification. In contrast, the middle and lower sections display ICD-10 codes (marked in the green boxes) that show selective connectivity to VASRD nodes. We expect this transform to significantly reduce false positives and improve the accuracy of our classification system.

findings.found_text: Figure 42 - Our ECE process generated 44,238 unique ICD-10 codes for 100 VASRD codes. After applying graph theory, we retained the 97.5th percentile of total ICD-10 codes (ECE output), resulting in 43,255 ICD-10 codes. We applied graph theory to these six conditions: Sarcoidosis, Brain Cancer, Asthma, Fibromyalgia, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, and Breast Cancer. For Sarcoidosis, Hannah's original set of 147 codes was narrowed down to 117 codes. Similarly, our ECE output for Sarcoidosis was refined from 2,564 to 2,289 codes after applying the same graph theory filtering, which comprehensively included all 117 of Hannah's codes.

The final step presents the results, displaying the VASRD mappings and medical codes, in a clear and actionable format.

findings.found_text: This image shows Step 2 of the VASRD Code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool where the system generates and displays extracted and expanded keywords based on inputs from Step 1. In the "Extracted Keywords" section, a table presents relevant medical terms associated with the condition, automatically extracted from eCFR descriptions and expanded using large language models based on the disease. The system has filtered these keywords to include only those relevant to the disease while removing duplicates and unnecessary terms, creating a focused set of medical terminology for mapping purposes.

findings.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
findings.found_text: This image displays Step 3 of the VASRD code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool, showing the final mapping from VASRD Code to ICD-10 codes. The "Filtered Clinical Codes" section presents a table of ICD-10 codes that have been identified as relevant to the disease(Sarcoidosis, VASRD code 6846). In this final step, the keywords generated in Step 2 are sent to the UMLS API, which maps them to relevant medical codes. These API results are then processed through a language model for post-filtering, which retains only the codes specifically related to the disease based on code descriptions while removing unrelated results.

3.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
3.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.

4.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

11.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

20.found_text: This table compares ECEU results across multiple medical conditions. Each row lists a condition and its associated VASRD code, detailing the clinical code mapping. The "Source Codes" column displays the initial validated codes, while the "ECEU Results“ column captures the unfiltered mapping output. The "Filtered ECEU Results" column highlights the significant reduction in false positives after LLM processing, ranging from 43% (Sarcoidosis) to 77% (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). The "Common Codes" column confirms retention of over 90% of source codes for most conditions, while “Missing Codes” tracks minimal losses. This comparative analysis demonstrates how our approach substantially improves precision in VASRD-to-medical code and preserves comprehensive coverage across diverse medical conditions.

The "Source Codes" column displays the initial validated codes, while the "ECEU Results“ column captures the unfiltered mapping output. The "Filtered ECEU Results" column highlights the significant reduction in false positives after LLM processing, ranging from 43% (Sarcoidosis) to 77% (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). The "Common Codes" column confirms retention of over 90% of source codes for most conditions, while “Missing Codes” tracks minimal losses. This comparative analysis demonstrates how our approach substantially improves precision in VASRD-to-medical code and preserves comprehensive coverage across diverse medical conditions.

21.found_text: These images show Step 1 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool. Users enter three key inputs: a 4-digit VASRD code (comma-separated for multiples), the associated disability (e.g., “Sarcoidosis,” as shown in the right-hand image), and the desired coding standard (as shown within the dropdown menu in the right-hand image). After providing the necessary input, the users select the "Step 2: Generate Keywords" button to proceed.

22.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
22.found_text: These images show Step 2 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, where the system generates and displays extracted and expanded keywords according to inputs from Step 1. After clicking "Generate Keywords" in the previous step, the system processes the given input and presents a table of relevant medical terms associated with the condition. LLMs automatically extract these terms from eCFR descriptions and expand them based on the specified disability. The system filters these keywords to retain only those relevant to the disability, removing any duplicates or unnecessary terms to create a focused set of medical mapping terminology.

28.found_text: This image shows the final step (Step 3) of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, which displays the complete VASRD to ICD-10 mapping results. After the UMLS API processes the keywords, the system presents a comprehensive table of filtered medical codes matched to the selected VASRD code and disability. The panel on the left-hand side shows a summary view of the results, while the image on the right-hand side displays the full expanded view, including all mapped codes. To save these mapping results, users click the "Download Final Result CSV" button.

31.found_text: These network visualizations depict the relationships between VASRD codes (purple hub nodes) and their associated CPT procedural codes (blue nodes). The directed arrows labelled "HAS_CPT" show which CPT codes map to each VASRD rating category, illustrating the medical classification mapping used in disability evaluation systems.

32.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.

The function tokenizes the input text into words, converts them to lowercase for uniformity, and removes common stopwords to focus on meaningful terms. It lemmatizes the tokens, reducing them to their base or root form, and removes punctuation and special characters to eliminate unnecessary noise. Additionally, duplicate words are removed while preserving the order of occurrence. Finally, the cleaned tokens are joined back into a single string. This cleaning process is crucial because the eCFR descriptions contain a lot of noise and repeated words, making them unsuitable for embedding and similarity measurement.

44.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
44.found_text: Figure 33 - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.

45.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
45.found_text: Figure 34 – The image shows the Voronoi polygon for Sarcoidosis. Voronoi is performed for 6 ECFR health conditions. For detailed analysis, we focused on one seed point, Sarcoidosis. From the Voronoi results, we identified 5,487 ICD-10 codes (data points) associated with Sarcoidosis (seed point). To evaluate these results, we compared them with Hannah's team's result, which contains 147 ICD-10 codes related to Sarcoidosis. Out of Voronoi's identified codes, 47 matched the existing list. While the match is limited, this result reflects some inherent challenges. Each data point is assigned to only one seed point region, which might not fully capture cases where data points could relate to multiple health conditions. Additionally, the dimensionality reduction step (PCA), though essential for visualization, may have contributed to minor distortions in the clustering.

46.found_text: Table 3 - The table illustrates how data points are distributed among four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, based on embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. Voronoi partitioning was applied using cosine similarity, which assigns each data point to the seed point with the highest similarity. This method allows for the grouping of data points based on their similarity to the seed points, providing a structured way to categorize ECFR descriptions. By examining these groupings, we gain valuable insights into the relationships and relevance of ICD-10 codes to each seed point, shedding light on how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

47.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
47.found_text: Table 4 - The table shows how data points are distributed among the four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, which are based on the embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. To analyze the data, Voronoi partitioning was applied using Euclidean distance. This method assigns each data point to the nearest seed point by calculating the Euclidean distance between the data point and the seed points. This approach helps identify patterns and relationships between ECFR descriptions and their closest seed points, offering a structured way to group similar data. By analyzing these groupings, we gain insights into the relevance of each seed point to the ICD-10 codes, uncovering how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

48.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
48.found_text: Figure 35 - The figure illustrates the architecture of a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. The process begins by embedding ICD-10 code descriptions into a vector embeddings using text-embedding-3-large embedding model. These embeddings are stored in a vector database to enable efficient semantic search. When a user submits a health condition as a query, it is converted into a vector embedding and passed to a retriever, which searches the vector database to find the most relevant ICD-10 descriptions. The retrieved information is then fed into a large language model (LLM), which combines this contextual input with its pretrained knowledge to generate a comprehensive and query-specific response. This integrated process of retrieval and generation ensures precise, relevant, and highly contextualized outputs for medical code queries.

49.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
49.found_text: Figure 36 – This work builds upon the concepts discussed in Slide 26, extending the implementation to refine the RAG pipeline for ICD-10 code retrieval and generation. The RAG pipeline combines vector embeddings and LLM to retrieve ICD-10 codes based on input queries. Vector embeddings are generated for ICD-10 code descriptions and stored in a FAISS index utilizing IndexFlatL2, which relies on L2 norm (Euclidean distance) for similarity searches. During the retrieval process, an embedding is generated for the input query and compared with the stored embeddings to retrieve the top k results. The retrieval process is configured with k=500, the top 500 most relevant ICD-10 codes are retained based on similarity ranking. Analysis shows that only 29 of the ICD-10 codes matched within the top 500 results, leaving 118 ICD-10 codes unretrieved. Since the generation process in RAG relies on the retrieved data, any missing codes in the retrieval stage are inherently excluded from the generation phase. This dependency emphasizes that the quality and completeness of the retrieved data directly impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the generated results. Without retrieving all relevant codes, the generated output may fail to capture the full scope of the input query, making the current RAG approach insufficient.

51.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
51.found_text: Figure 38 - This diagram demonstrates our conceptual framework for graph-based ICD-10 filtering. Here we visualize the (synthetic) connectivity patterns between ICD-10 (dark blue dots) and VASRD codes (light blue dots). The diagram showcases two distinct patterns of code relationships: Looking at the top section, we see examples of indiscriminate ICD-10 codes (marked in the red boxes) that are overconnected to multiple VASRD nodes. These create a complex web of relationships, indicating low selectivity and a high probability of false positives. Such codes are less useful for precise medical classification. In contrast, the middle and lower sections display ICD-10 codes (marked in the green boxes) that show selective connectivity to VASRD nodes. We expect this transform to significantly reduce false positives and improve the accuracy of our classification system.

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) lacks a structured, scalable system to map Veterans Affairs Schedule for Rating Disabilities (VASRD) codes to standardized medical codes. This gap makes it difficult for adjudicators to efficiently evaluate claims, leading to processing delays and inconsistent evaluations. Amida’s MCP team currently performs this mapping manually, which is time-consuming and not scalable.

bullets.found_text: ​The VACM automation initiative enables the MCP team to accelerate the mapping process, expediting over 114,000 claims and reducing claim resolution time for more than 4.4 million veterans.

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.
bullets.suggestion: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU); In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR); In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms; The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage; The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).
bullets.suggestion: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow; Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count)

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: This table compares ECEU results across multiple medical conditions. Each row lists a condition and its associated VASRD code, detailing the clinical code mapping. The "Source Codes" column displays the initial validated codes, while the "ECEU Results“ column captures the unfiltered mapping output. The "Filtered ECEU Results" column highlights the significant reduction in false positives after LLM processing, ranging from 43% (Sarcoidosis) to 77% (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). The "Common Codes" column confirms retention of over 90% of source codes for most conditions, while “Missing Codes” tracks minimal losses. This comparative analysis demonstrates how our approach substantially improves precision in VASRD-to-medical code and preserves comprehensive coverage across diverse medical conditions.

bullets.found_text: Figure 24 – The diagram illustrates a workflow for calculating cosine similarity between eCFR descriptions and ICD-10 descriptions. Step 1 involves obtaining the eCFR description, followed by preprocessing the textual data to clean and standardize it. In Step 2, both eCFR and ICD-10 descriptions are fed into an embedding model, which converts the text into numerical vector representations. The ICD-10 Description is extracted from the output retrieved through the UMLS API. In Step 4, vectors are stored for further use. Finally, Step 5 utilizes cosine similarity to measure the degree of similarity between the eCFR description and ICD-10 description.

bullets.found_text: Figure 25– This code snippet demonstrates a preprocessing function called preprocess_ecfr. The function tokenizes the input text into words, converts them to lowercase for uniformity, and removes common stopwords to focus on meaningful terms. It lemmatizes the tokens, reducing them to their base or root form, and removes punctuation and special characters to eliminate unnecessary noise. Additionally, duplicate words are removed while preserving the order of occurrence. Finally, the cleaned tokens are joined back into a single string. This cleaning process is crucial because the eCFR descriptions contain a lot of noise and repeated words, making them unsuitable for embedding and similarity measurement.

bullets.found_text: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved 33 matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had 28 matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only 1 code. PubMedBERT and BioBERT yielded fewer matches in the top 200 results because their embeddings focus on biomedical text, which may not align well with the regulatory and clinical language in the ECFR description, resulting in weaker semantic connections

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: Figure 31 – Euclidean distance is used to measure the similarity between two points. In this analysis, vector embeddings were generated for the Sarcoidosis ECFR description and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions using the text-embedding-3-large. Without applying normalization or dimensionality reduction, the L2 norm is calculated. ICD-10 Codes were sorted based on their L2 norm scores, with lower scores indicating higher similarity. The top 200 codes with the lowest L2 norm scores were compared to a curated list of 147 Sarcoidosis-related ICD-10 codes. Among the top 200 codes, 20 matched the curated list, and in the top 500, 29 codes matched. While the match is limited, refining the ECFR description by incorporating all known symptoms of Sarcoidosis using a LLM has the potential to improve the relevance and accuracy of the results.

bullets.found_text: Figure 32 -  In our analysis, Euclidean distance serves as a key metric to evaluate the semantic relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions across two distinct datasets: API output results and Hannah's codes. The API output encompasses 2,564 codes, while Hannah's dataset contains 147 thoroughly validated codes. Our Euclidean distance calculations revealed a distribution ranging from 0.4754 to 0.7904 in the API dataset and 0.4754 to 0.7617 in Hannah's dataset. Notably, the overlapping distance ranges indicate that Euclidean distance, may not provide optimal differentiation for identifying the 147 validated codes within the broader API Output Results.

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: Figure 33 - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: Figure 34 – The image shows the Voronoi polygon for Sarcoidosis. Voronoi is performed for 6 ECFR health conditions. For detailed analysis, we focused on one seed point, Sarcoidosis. From the Voronoi results, we identified 5,487 ICD-10 codes (data points) associated with Sarcoidosis (seed point). To evaluate these results, we compared them with Hannah's team's result, which contains 147 ICD-10 codes related to Sarcoidosis. Out of Voronoi's identified codes, 47 matched the existing list. While the match is limited, this result reflects some inherent challenges. Each data point is assigned to only one seed point region, which might not fully capture cases where data points could relate to multiple health conditions. Additionally, the dimensionality reduction step (PCA), though essential for visualization, may have contributed to minor distortions in the clustering.

bullets.found_text: Table 3 - The table illustrates how data points are distributed among four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, based on embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. Voronoi partitioning was applied using cosine similarity, which assigns each data point to the seed point with the highest similarity. This method allows for the grouping of data points based on their similarity to the seed points, providing a structured way to categorize ECFR descriptions. By examining these groupings, we gain valuable insights into the relationships and relevance of ICD-10 codes to each seed point, shedding light on how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: Figure 35 - The figure illustrates the architecture of a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. The process begins by embedding ICD-10 code descriptions into a vector embeddings using text-embedding-3-large embedding model. These embeddings are stored in a vector database to enable efficient semantic search. When a user submits a health condition as a query, it is converted into a vector embedding and passed to a retriever, which searches the vector database to find the most relevant ICD-10 descriptions. The retrieved information is then fed into a large language model (LLM), which combines this contextual input with its pretrained knowledge to generate a comprehensive and query-specific response. This integrated process of retrieval and generation ensures precise, relevant, and highly contextualized outputs for medical code queries.

bullets.description: Bullets: capitalize the first word; replace internal sentence breaks with semicolons; avoid periods at the end of bullet points.
bullets.found_text: Figure 36 – This work builds upon the concepts discussed in Slide 26, extending the implementation to refine the RAG pipeline for ICD-10 code retrieval and generation. The RAG pipeline combines vector embeddings and LLM to retrieve ICD-10 codes based on input queries. Vector embeddings are generated for ICD-10 code descriptions and stored in a FAISS index utilizing IndexFlatL2, which relies on L2 norm (Euclidean distance) for similarity searches. During the retrieval process, an embedding is generated for the input query and compared with the stored embeddings to retrieve the top k results. The retrieval process is configured with k=500, the top 500 most relevant ICD-10 codes are retained based on similarity ranking. Analysis shows that only 29 of the ICD-10 codes matched within the top 500 results, leaving 118 ICD-10 codes unretrieved. Since the generation process in RAG relies on the retrieved data, any missing codes in the retrieval stage are inherently excluded from the generation phase. This dependency emphasizes that the quality and completeness of the retrieved data directly impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the generated results. Without retrieving all relevant codes, the generated output may fail to capture the full scope of the input query, making the current RAG approach insufficient.

bullets.found_text: Figure 38 - This diagram demonstrates our conceptual framework for graph-based ICD-10 filtering. Here we visualize the (synthetic) connectivity patterns between ICD-10 (dark blue dots) and VASRD codes (light blue dots). The diagram showcases two distinct patterns of code relationships: Looking at the top section, we see examples of indiscriminate ICD-10 codes (marked in the red boxes) that are overconnected to multiple VASRD nodes. These create a complex web of relationships, indicating low selectivity and a high probability of false positives. Such codes are less useful for precise medical classification. In contrast, the middle and lower sections display ICD-10 codes (marked in the green boxes) that show selective connectivity to VASRD nodes. We expect this transform to significantly reduce false positives and improve the accuracy of our classification system.

numerals.description: Spell out numbers <100 (and at sentence start). Keep numerals for percent/million/billion unless sentence start. Use commas for 4+ digits (except dates/IDs/URLs/years).
numerals.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.
numerals.suggestion: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama three.two to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.

numerals.description: Spell out numbers <100 (and at sentence start). Keep numerals for percent/million/billion unless sentence start. Use commas for 4+ digits (except dates/IDs/URLs/years).
numerals.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.nine for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93,306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

After clicking "Generate Keywords" in the previous step, the system processes the given input and presents a table of relevant medical terms associated with the condition. The system filters these keywords to retain only those relevant to the disability, removing any duplicates or unnecessary terms to create a focused set of medical mapping terminology.

numerals.found_text: Figure 24 – The diagram illustrates a workflow for calculating cosine similarity between eCFR descriptions and ICD-10 descriptions. Step 1 involves obtaining the eCFR description, followed by preprocessing the textual data to clean and standardize it. In Step 2, both eCFR and ICD-10 descriptions are fed into an embedding model, which converts the text into numerical vector representations. The ICD-10 Description is extracted from the output retrieved through the UMLS API. In Step 4, vectors are stored for further use. Finally, Step 5 utilizes cosine similarity to measure the degree of similarity between the eCFR description and ICD-10 description.
numerals.suggestion: Figure twenty-four – The diagram illustrates a workflow for calculating cosine similarity between eCFR descriptions and ICD-10 descriptions. Step one involves obtaining the eCFR description, followed by preprocessing the textual data to clean and standardize it. In Step two, both eCFR and ICD-10 descriptions are fed into an embedding model, which converts the text into numerical vector representations. The ICD-10 Description is extracted from the output retrieved through the UMLS API. In Step four, vectors are stored for further use. Finally, Step five utilizes cosine similarity to measure the degree of similarity between the eCFR description and ICD-10 description.

numerals.found_text: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved 33 matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had 28 matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only 1 code. PubMedBERT and BioBERT yielded fewer matches in the top 200 results because their embeddings focus on biomedical text, which may not align well with the regulatory and clinical language in the ECFR description, resulting in weaker semantic connections
numerals.suggestion: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved thirty-three matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had twenty-eight matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only one code. numerals.found_text: Figure 30 -  Cosine similarity analysis was implemented to quantify the textual relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions. The computed similarity scores exhibited a range from 0.6876 to 0.8870 in the API output results, while Hannah's codes demonstrated scores from 0.7099 to 0.8870. Although cosine similarity excels at measuring textual alignment between vector representations, the substantial overlap in score distributions suggests its limitations in distinctly separating the approved codes from the broader API output set. This overlap presents a significant challenge in reliably identifying and ranking the 147 validated codes within the top 500 results.

numerals.found_text: Figure 31 – Euclidean distance is used to measure the similarity between two points. In this analysis, vector embeddings were generated for the Sarcoidosis ECFR description and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions using the text-embedding-3-large. Without applying normalization or dimensionality reduction, the L2 norm is calculated. ICD-10 Codes were sorted based on their L2 norm scores, with lower scores indicating higher similarity. The top 200 codes with the lowest L2 norm scores were compared to a curated list of 147 Sarcoidosis-related ICD-10 codes. Among the top 200 codes, 20 matched the curated list, and in the top 500, 29 codes matched. While the match is limited, refining the ECFR description by incorporating all known symptoms of Sarcoidosis using a LLM has the potential to improve the relevance and accuracy of the results.

Among the top 200 codes, twenty matched the curated list, and in the top 500, twenty-nine codes matched. While the match is limited, refining the ECFR description by incorporating all known symptoms of Sarcoidosis using a LLM has the potential to improve the relevance and accuracy of the results.

numerals.found_text: Figure 32 -  In our analysis, Euclidean distance serves as a key metric to evaluate the semantic relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions across two distinct datasets: API output results and Hannah's codes. The API output encompasses 2,564 codes, while Hannah's dataset contains 147 thoroughly validated codes. Our Euclidean distance calculations revealed a distribution ranging from 0.4754 to 0.7904 in the API dataset and 0.4754 to 0.7617 in Hannah's dataset. Notably, the overlapping distance ranges indicate that Euclidean distance, may not provide optimal differentiation for identifying the 147 validated codes within the broader API Output Results.

numerals.description: Spell out numbers <100 (and at sentence start). Keep numerals for percent/million/billion unless sentence start. Use commas for 4+ digits (except dates/IDs/URLs/years).
numerals.found_text: Figure 33 - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.
numerals.suggestion: Figure thirty-three - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately seventy-five,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the center of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.

numerals.found_text: Figure 34 – The image shows the Voronoi polygon for Sarcoidosis. Voronoi is performed for 6 ECFR health conditions. For detailed analysis, we focused on one seed point, Sarcoidosis. From the Voronoi results, we identified 5,487 ICD-10 codes (data points) associated with Sarcoidosis (seed point). To evaluate these results, we compared them with Hannah's team's result, which contains 147 ICD-10 codes related to Sarcoidosis. Out of Voronoi's identified codes, 47 matched the existing list. While the match is limited, this result reflects some inherent challenges. Each data point is assigned to only one seed point region, which might not fully capture cases where data points could relate to multiple health conditions. Additionally, the dimensionality reduction step (PCA), though essential for visualization, may have contributed to minor distortions in the clustering.

numerals.found_text: Table 3 - The table illustrates how data points are distributed among four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, based on embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. Voronoi partitioning was applied using cosine similarity, which assigns each data point to the seed point with the highest similarity. This method allows for the grouping of data points based on their similarity to the seed points, providing a structured way to categorize ECFR descriptions. By examining these groupings, we gain valuable insights into the relationships and relevance of ICD-10 codes to each seed point, shedding light on how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

numerals.found_text: Table 4 - The table shows how data points are distributed among the four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, which are based on the embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. To analyze the data, Voronoi partitioning was applied using Euclidean distance. This method assigns each data point to the nearest seed point by calculating the Euclidean distance between the data point and the seed points. This approach helps identify patterns and relationships between ECFR descriptions and their closest seed points, offering a structured way to group similar data. By analyzing these groupings, we gain insights into the relevance of each seed point to the ICD-10 codes, uncovering how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

numerals.found_text: Figure 35 - The figure illustrates the architecture of a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. The process begins by embedding ICD-10 code descriptions into a vector embeddings using text-embedding-3-large embedding model. These embeddings are stored in a vector database to enable efficient semantic search. When a user submits a health condition as a query, it is converted into a vector embedding and passed to a retriever, which searches the vector database to find the most relevant ICD-10 descriptions. The retrieved information is then fed into a large language model (LLM), which combines this contextual input with its pretrained knowledge to generate a comprehensive and query-specific response. This integrated process of retrieval and generation ensures precise, relevant, and highly contextualized outputs for medical code queries.

numerals.found_text: Figure 36 – This work builds upon the concepts discussed in Slide 26, extending the implementation to refine the RAG pipeline for ICD-10 code retrieval and generation. The RAG pipeline combines vector embeddings and LLM to retrieve ICD-10 codes based on input queries. Vector embeddings are generated for ICD-10 code descriptions and stored in a FAISS index utilizing IndexFlatL2, which relies on L2 norm (Euclidean distance) for similarity searches. During the retrieval process, an embedding is generated for the input query and compared with the stored embeddings to retrieve the top k results. The retrieval process is configured with k=500, the top 500 most relevant ICD-10 codes are retained based on similarity ranking. Analysis shows that only 29 of the ICD-10 codes matched within the top 500 results, leaving 118 ICD-10 codes unretrieved. Since the generation process in RAG relies on the retrieved data, any missing codes in the retrieval stage are inherently excluded from the generation phase. This dependency emphasizes that the quality and completeness of the retrieved data directly impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the generated results. Without retrieving all relevant codes, the generated output may fail to capture the full scope of the input query, making the current RAG approach insufficient.

Analysis shows that only twenty-nine of the ICD-10 codes matched within the top 500 results, leaving 118 ICD-10 codes unretrieved. Since the generation process in RAG relies on the retrieved data, any missing codes in the retrieval stage are inherently excluded from the generation phase. This dependency emphasizes that the quality and completeness of the retrieved data directly impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the generated results. Without retrieving all relevant codes, the generated output may fail to capture the full scope of the input query, making the current RAG approach insufficient.

numerals.found_text: Figure 38 - This diagram demonstrates our conceptual framework for graph-based ICD-10 filtering. Here we visualize the (synthetic) connectivity patterns between ICD-10 (dark blue dots) and VASRD codes (light blue dots). The diagram showcases two distinct patterns of code relationships: Looking at the top section, we see examples of indiscriminate ICD-10 codes (marked in the red boxes) that are overconnected to multiple VASRD nodes. These create a complex web of relationships, indicating low selectivity and a high probability of false positives. Such codes are less useful for precise medical classification. In contrast, the middle and lower sections display ICD-10 codes (marked in the green boxes) that show selective connectivity to VASRD nodes. We expect this transform to significantly reduce false positives and improve the accuracy of our classification system.

We observe that multiple ICD-10 codes are linked to both unique VASRD codes, which aligns with our theory that these shared ICD codes contribute significantly to false positives. By identifying and removing these overlapping ICD-10 codes, we aim to effectively reduce false positives.

numerals.found_text: Figure 42 - Our ECE process generated 44,238 unique ICD-10 codes for 100 VASRD codes. After applying graph theory, we retained the 97.5th percentile of total ICD-10 codes (ECE output), resulting in 43,255 ICD-10 codes. We applied graph theory to these six conditions: Sarcoidosis, Brain Cancer, Asthma, Fibromyalgia, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, and Breast Cancer. For Sarcoidosis, Hannah's original set of 147 codes was narrowed down to 117 codes. Similarly, our ECE output for Sarcoidosis was refined from 2,564 to 2,289 codes after applying the same graph theory filtering, which comprehensively included all 117 of Hannah's codes.

numerals.found_text: This image shows Step 1 of the VASRD Code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool. In this initial step, users are prompted to enter three key inputs of information: a 4-digit VASRD Code (with comma separation for multiple codes), the Disease/Condition Name ('Sarcoidosis' is shown as an example), and the Medical Code Type ('ICD-10' is selected) to generate keywords.

numerals.found_text: This image shows Step 2 of the VASRD Code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool where the system generates and displays extracted and expanded keywords based on inputs from Step 1. In the "Extracted Keywords" section, a table presents relevant medical terms associated with the condition, automatically extracted from eCFR descriptions and expanded using large language models based on the disease. The system has filtered these keywords to include only those relevant to the disease while removing duplicates and unnecessary terms, creating a focused set of medical terminology for mapping purposes.

numerals.found_text: This image displays Step 3 of the VASRD code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool, showing the final mapping from VASRD Code to ICD-10 codes. The "Filtered Clinical Codes" section presents a table of ICD-10 codes that have been identified as relevant to the disease(Sarcoidosis, VASRD code 6846). In this final step, the keywords generated in Step 2 are sent to the UMLS API, which maps them to relevant medical codes. These API results are then processed through a language model for post-filtering, which retains only the codes specifically related to the disease based on code descriptions while removing unrelated results.
numerals.suggestion: This image displays Step three of the VASRD code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool, showing the final mapping from VASRD Code to ICD-10 codes. In this final step, the keywords generated in Step two are sent to the UMLS API, which maps them to relevant medical codes. These API results are then processed through a language model for post-filtering, which retains only the codes specifically related to the disease based on code descriptions while removing unrelated results.

titles.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
titles.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

titles.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
titles.found_text: This table compares ECEU results across multiple medical conditions. Each row lists a condition and its associated VASRD code, detailing the clinical code mapping. The "Source Codes" column displays the initial validated codes, while the "ECEU Results“ column captures the unfiltered mapping output. The "Filtered ECEU Results" column highlights the significant reduction in false positives after LLM processing, ranging from 43% (Sarcoidosis) to 77% (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). The "Common Codes" column confirms retention of over 90% of source codes for most conditions, while “Missing Codes” tracks minimal losses. This comparative analysis demonstrates how our approach substantially improves precision in VASRD-to-medical code and preserves comprehensive coverage across diverse medical conditions.

titles.found_text: These images show Step 1 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool. Users enter three key inputs: a 4-digit VASRD code (comma-separated for multiples), the associated disability (e.g., “Sarcoidosis,” as shown in the right-hand image), and the desired coding standard (as shown within the dropdown menu in the right-hand image). After providing the necessary input, the users select the "Step 2: Generate Keywords" button to proceed.
titles.suggestion: These images show Step 1 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool. Users enter three key inputs: a 4-digit VASRD code (comma-separated for multiples), the associated disability (e.g., “Sarcoidosis,” as shown in the right-hand image), and the desired coding standard (as shown within the dropdown menu in the right-hand image). After providing the necessary input, the users select the Step 2: Generate Keywords button to proceed.

titles.description: Document titles should be italicized, not quoted. Remove quotation marks and apply italics via formatting.
titles.found_text: These images show Step 2 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, where the system generates and displays extracted and expanded keywords according to inputs from Step 1. After clicking "Generate Keywords" in the previous step, the system processes the given input and presents a table of relevant medical terms associated with the condition. LLMs automatically extract these terms from eCFR descriptions and expand them based on the specified disability. The system filters these keywords to retain only those relevant to the disability, removing any duplicates or unnecessary terms to create a focused set of medical mapping terminology.

titles.found_text: These images show Step 3 of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, where users generate medical code mappings according to selected keywords. After reviewing the keywords in Step 2, users click the "Step 3: Filter Medical Codes" button to initiate the mapping process. The panel on the right-hand side shows the UMLS API actively processing the request.

titles.found_text: This image shows the final step (Step 3) of the VASRD-to-Medical Code Mapping Tool, which displays the complete VASRD to ICD-10 mapping results. After the UMLS API processes the keywords, the system presents a comprehensive table of filtered medical codes matched to the selected VASRD code and disability. The panel on the left-hand side shows a summary view of the results, while the image on the right-hand side displays the full expanded view, including all mapped codes. To save these mapping results, users click the "Download Final Result CSV" button.

titles.found_text: Figure 27– This slide demonstrates the implementation of vector embedding using the text-embedding-ada-002 model. The embeddings are computed for both the cleaned eCFR descriptions and the ICD-10 "Code Description" column. After computation, the embeddings are saved into a DataFrame for future use. The image shows the embedding process using text-embedding-ada-002, but embeddings were also created using the other three models: all-MiniLM-L6-v2, PubMedBERT, and BioBERT, to ensure a complete comparison.
